abstract.p: In this article, a hybrid electric propulsion system which consists of a fuel cell (FC) and a battery is proposed for an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) propulsion application. Based on the UAV propulsion power requirements during take-off, climb, endurance, and maximum velocity, the hybrid electric power plant specifications are defined to respond to any propulsion power demand. A power and energy management system is introduced to control the hybrid system power flow while optimizing the FC system performances. The power and energy management system consists of three sections called, power management system, power electronic interface, and energy management system. The power management system decides the operating power of the each power source based on the propulsion power demand and the battery state of charge. The power electronic interface is an implementation protocol of the power management decisions through a unidirectional power converter and a bidirectional power converter which are connected to the FC, the battery, and the DC bus. Based on the FC current decided by the power management system, the energy management system controls the air supply system of the FC to maximize the FC system net power output. A referenced model is used to obtain the optimum inlet air pressure of the FC and a neuro-fuzzy-based adaptive control architecture adapts the FC air compressor power to the optimum value. The results show that the optimum compressor power configuration is superior than the constant power configuration.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Long endurance electric unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are emerged in modern aerospace industry due to the recent technological advances in electric propulsion and modern mission requirement. The electric propulsion directly converts the chemical energy into mechanical power without internal or external combustion. The proposed hybrid electric UAV propulsion system mainly consisted of a proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC), a Li-Ion battery and a permanent magnet brushless (PMBL) DC motor and power converters. The FC/ battery hybrid configuration shows a potential to replace conventional combustion engines from the UAV due to the high power and energy densities of the hybrid system. The PMBL DC motor has advantages such as high efficiency, high speed range, reduced acoustic operation and improved speed versus torque characteristics [1, 2]. In addition, the PEM FC and the Li-Ion battery hybrid power plant has higher energy conversion efficiency than the similar size combustion engine [3]. The PEM FC powered UAV's endurance capability has improved considerably due to the high energy density of the power plant [4, 5]. In addition to that, the electric propulsion is considered as an environment friendly propulsion concept due to its stealth operation and minimum carbon emissions.

The propeller driven piston engine aircraft efficiency is low at the high-speed operation and much noisier than the low speed operation [6]. The wax deposit inside the fuel storage at low temperature is an another drawback of the piston engine driven aircraft [6]. Therefore, the propeller driven aircrafts were developed with low r/min piston engines with variable pitch propellers. In the electric powered aircrafts, the high speed PMBL DC motors can operate at higher efficiencies than the piston engines and hence eliminate the requirement of the low-speed propeller operation.

In the hybrid electric propulsion, the power management system controls the power flow between the propulsion system and the power plant. The FC system is combined with the Li-Ion battery as the secondary power source to supply the additional power required for take-off and climb [2]. In addition to that, the secondary power source eliminates the FC stack transient delay caused by the chemical reaction. The importance of the FC system power management with the secondary power source has been described in [7] and outlined the requirement of the advanced control architecture for hybrid power sharing.

The proposed power and energy management system is a control architecture which has three sections called, energy management system, power management system, and power electronic interface. The energy management system optimizes the energy usage of the PEM FC system. The power management system decides the operating power mode of the propulsion system and develops the logical sequences for the power electronic interface to switch the current flow direction of the power plant. The power electronic interface is the implementation protocol of the power management system decisions through a bidirectional and a unidirectional power converters according to the propulsion power demand.

The proposed power and energy management architecture will be discussed in following sections. In Section 2, the UAV propulsion power requirements during the different flying conditions are derived. The hybrid electric propulsion is discussed in Section 3. In Section 4, a power and energy management system is introduced to control the hybrid system power flow. An adaptive control architecture for the energy management system is discussed in Section 5. The hybrid power plant specifications are defined in Section 6. Simulation results are discussed in Section 7 and concluded in Section 8.

sec.title: 2 UAV PROPULSION POWER REQUIREMENT
sec.p:
The propulsion power requirement during the mission is depended on the flying modes of the aircraft such as aircraft take-off, climb, cruising, endurance, descent, and landing. Initially, the aircraft critical parameters are analysed for a specific intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) mission. Then, the propulsion power required for the aircraft take-off, the climb, the endurance, and the maximum velocity modes is obtained. The hybrid UAV performance specifications described in reference [8] are considered for the FC UAV propulsion analysis. The proposed aircraft performance requirements are shown in Table 1. Table 1

sec.title: 3 HYBRID ELECTRIC PROPULSION
sec.p:
A regulated hybrid power architecture which consists of a PEMFC system, a Li-Ion battery, a DC/DC boost converter, a DC/DC bidirectional converter and a PMBL DC motor with a three-phase inverter is proposed for the FC-UAV. Figure 1 shows the schematic diagram of the hybrid power plant. The compressed hydrogen cylinder supplies the required hydrogen gas to the PEM FC system and a hydrogen regulator controls hydrogen pressure and flow rate. The FC system air compressor pressurizes the inlet manifold air supply. The hydrogen and the oxygen gases are reacted at the electrodes and produce electricity, water, and heat. The unidirectional power converter (UDC) boosts the PEMFC voltage output and regulates the DC bus voltage. The bidirectional converter (BDC) boosts the battery voltage during the high power state and operates as a buck converter during the low power state of the propulsion system. The three-phase inverter converts the DC supply into the three-phase signals. The PMBL DC motor speed is controlled by varying the duty ratios of the inverter signals based on the sensor feedback. sec.title: 4 POWER AND ENERGY MANAGEMENT
sec.p:
The power and energy management is a process which addresses power flow and energy usage for each power source. The power and energy management system (PEMS) is sectioned into three subsystems called, energy management system (EMS), power management system (PMS), and power electronic interface (PEI). The energy management system formulates the strategies to optimize the energy usage of the PEMFC. The PMS decides the amount of power shared with each power source by controlling the unidirectional and the bidirectional power converters. The PEI regulates the power converters currents and voltages according to the pulse width modulations (PWM) signals. Figure 2 shows the flow diagram of the power and energy management system. Fig. 2
Power and energy management system Fig. 3
Power management system decision flow chart

In the power and energy management architecture, the hybrid power plant operating power is divided into three states called, start-up, charging, and the high power. The power management system decides the operating power state based on the battery terminal voltage and the DC bus current. In each power state, the current flow is controlled by the UDC and the BDC power converters. As the second stage of the control architecture, the PEMFC air supply system is controlled based on the FC current determined by the power management system. The referenced model obtains the optimum compressor power and adapts the actual system to the optimum state.

sec.title: 4.1 Power management system
sec.p:
The power management system consists of a power sharing algorithm which decides the operating power state of the hybrid system. The power management system is developed as a state machine and the states are transited based on the DC bus current and the battery terminal voltage. The power management algorithm is shown in flowchart (Fig. 3). The Start-up process of the power plant is activated at the initial stage of the propulsion and later the operating state is varied between the high power and the charging states. The Start-up state prevents the FC system transient delay and allows the battery to supply the propulsion power. If the battery power is not sufficient, an external power supply is required to power the FC balance of plant. Figure 4 shows the current flow during the start-up state of the PMS. Fig. 4
Hybrid system current flow during the start-up state

The start-up condition remains until the FC system generates the electricity. When the FC system is gradually increased to the rated power level, the PMS switches the BDC into the buck mode and starts the initial charging before the aircraft takeoff. The FC system supplies the propulsion power and charges the battery until the battery terminal voltage (Bat vol) > 12 V. Figure 5 shows the current flow direction of the propulsion system during the battery charging state. Fig. 5
Hybrid system current flow during the charging state

After the battery is fully charged, the BDC is switched back the boost mode and increases the propeller motor speed for the aircraft takeoff. Then, the high power state is activated and remains until the aircraft has achieved desired altitude or velocity. At this stage, the BDC and the UDC are operated in the boost mode. The power flow during the high power state is shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6
Hybrid system current flow during the high power state

sec.title: 4.2 Power electronic interface
sec.p:
The power electronic interface consisted with an unidirectional boost converter for the PEMFC system and a bidirectional converter for the Li-Ion battery. Non-isolated PWM-controlled DC/DC power converters are developed to regulate the power flow of the hybrid system. The UDC and the BDC are operated in voltage control mode or current control mode depending on the DC bus current. When the DC bus current is lower than the propulsion system rated value, the UDC is operated in the voltage control mode and the BDC is operated in the current control mode. If the DC bus current is higher than the rated value, the UDC is operated in the current control mode and the BDC is switched to the voltage control mode. Table 4 shows the control modes of the UDC and the BDC at the high power and the charging power states. The amount of load current distributed between the PEMFC and the battery is changed by varying the PWM signals duty ratios. The voltage and the current compensators generate the errors between the referenced values of the DC bus voltage/current and the actual values. Based on the current or the voltage error, the PWM signal duty ratio is determined. Figure 7 shows the schematic diagram of the voltage and the current regulation processes at the DC bus. Fig. 7

sec.title: 5 ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
sec.p:
The energy management system is developed to optimize the energy usage of the FC system. The air-supplying system of the PEMFC system is controlled to obtain the maximum net power output from the FC system. When the FC system air supply pressure and flowrate are increased, the cell voltage is increased due to the minimization of the oxygen concentration loss [12]. However, the FC system compressor consumes additional power for the pressurization. Hence, the FC stack power gained is reduced by the additional power consumed by the compressor motor. The relationship between the net power gained Pnet and the compressor pressure ratio ( (p2p1)) are expressed in (8), as described in [12]. (8) where n is the number of cells, i the FC current, C a constant for the FC system, T the cell temperature, and efficiencies of the compressor and compressor motors are ηm and ηc. The FC system net power gain at different pressure ratios are plotted in Fig. 8. The Pnet is gradually increased to the maximum level and later reduces due to the power consumed by the compressor motor. Fig. 8
Fuel cell net power variations with the pressure ratio

The FC system maximum net power output at the various FC currents are selected from the peak values of Fig. 8. Based on the pressure ratios of the peak values, the optimum compressor power is formulated as a function of the FC current shown in (9). Figure 9 shows the variation of the optimum compressor power with the FC current (9) The optimum compressor power can be represented as the optimum compressor motor voltage by considering the relationship of the compressor and the compressor motor characteristics. The compressor map is used to determine the optimum air flowrates for the different pressure ratios. In order to generate the optimum pressure ratio and the flowrate, the compressor motor speed is changed according to the FC current variations. The required optimum air flowrate and the optimum pressure can be achieved by varying the terminal voltage of the compressor motor. However, investigating the compressor characteristics and the compressor motor control methods deviate from the scope of this article. Therefore, the compressor power is considered for the control architecture analysis. Fig. 9

sec.title: 5.1 Adaptive control strategy
sec.p: The FC air supply system should maintain the optimum compressor power to maximize the FC system net power output during the mission. In the literature, the control approaches such as PI controllers, fuzzy logic, neural networks, optimal control, adaptive control, and genetic algorithm were mostly used as the FC control methodologies. However, in dynamic systems, the applicability of the control methodology is bounded by the limitations on gain, overshoot, and time response. An advanced control architecture with online learning and training algorithms gives considerable benefits in terms of the controllability of the non-linear system. Adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) can learn from the feedbacks and trains the system output to achieve the referenced value [13]. The main advantages of the ANFIS based control architecture are the dynamic adaptability to the non-linear system and ability to define the approximated initial conditions for the training process from the fuzzy logic rule based [14].

In the FC control architecture, the optimum compressor power which is described in equation (9) is implemented as the referenced model to the ANFIS controller which adapts the actual compressor power to the optimum value in each time step. The schematic diagram of the adaptive controller is shown in (10).

Figure shows that the input parameters Ifc and SoC are trained to produce the optimum compressor power in the ANFIS controller and the control signal is sent to the actual plant. Initially, the controller operates as a fuzzy logic controller and after several time steps (10 s for this analysis), it operates as the ANFIS controller. After identifying the initial conditions of the compressor optimum power, the ANFIS controller starts the online training process. The layered fuzzification structure which is developed with the neural network feedback loops trains the fuzzy output using the back-propagation algorithm and the error minimization algorithm. Figure 11 shows the network representation of the ANFIS controller. The back-propagation algorithm trains the actual compressor power (Pcom) to achieve the optimum value (Pcom op). The error minimization algorithm minimizes the error between the Pcom and the Pcom op. The ANFIS controller has a rule-based system to generate the initial condition for the compressor power based on the battery SoC and the FC current. Fig. 10
The schematic diagram of the ANFIS controller Fig. 11
The network representation of the adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system

sec.title: 5.2 Fuzzy logic decisions
sec.p: The air supply system control decisions are included in the fuzzy logic rule based to decide the FC system compressor operating power. The fuzzy controller input parameters are the FC current (Ifc) and the battery SoC. The compressor power (Pcom) is the fuzzy output. The fuzzy logic membership functions are defined based on the linguistics rules which represent the dynamic characteristics of the hybrid system. The fuzzy logic system consists of four different layers, the fuzzification interface, the fuzzy rule based, the fuzzy inference machine, and the defuzzification interface.

sec.title: 6 HYBRID POWER PLANT SPECIFICATIONS
sec.p:
The PEM FC and the Li-Ion battery hybrid power plant specifications are defined based on the maximum power demand from the propulsion system. It is assumed that the power consumed by the aircraft payload is constant at 70 W. The DC bus voltage is constant at 48 V when the power converters operate in the voltage control mode. Table 6 shows the DC bus current for each flying mode. In order to response the DC current, the power sources and the power converter specifications are defined. Table 6

The 500 W Horizon PEMFC system [9] is selected for the analysis. The PEMFC system-rated current and voltage are 22 V and 23.5 A, respectively. The FC system output voltage range is 19 V − 35 V. The UDC maximum input power is limited to the FC system 500 W rated power. The UDC high voltage (HV) side is constant at 48 V. The UDC efficiency is 88 per cent. Therefore, the UDC maximum HV current is limited 9.5 A.

When the propulsion system demands power more than 500 W, the FC system operates at rated level and the battery provides balance of the power demand. When the UAV is taking off, the BDC operates in the boost mode and the BDC HV side current is IBDCHV max=12.5 A. The BDC output voltage VBDCHV is always maintained lower than the VDCbus = 48 V. The battery lowest voltage (Vbat min) which is the BDC low voltage side VBDCLV is 24 V. The BDC efficiency is 88 per cent. During the take-off period, the maximum current drawn by the battery is 28.4A at 24 V.
During the buck mode, the battery charging voltage (VBDCbuck chg) is 25 V. The battery maximum charging current IBDCbuck max is 2 A.

sec.title: 7 SIMULATION AND ANALYSIS
sec.p: The hybrid propulsion system was modelled in Matlab Simpower system tool box and the ANFIS control architecture was developed in Simulink. The DC bus current profile which is shown in Table 6 was simulated to verify the robustness of the proposed control architecture. Initially, the performances of the power management system was investigated. Later, the FC current profile obtained from the power management was used to verify the energy management performances. The EMS performances were compared with a optimum compressor power and a constant compressor power.

The PMBL motor was loaded with a mechanical torque in order to generate the required DC bus current profile. The DC bus current profile which is obtained from the simulations is shown in Fig. 17. Fig. 17
DC bus current variations

The start-up state was limited to the 100 s and then, the high power state was activated for 60 s time period. The charging power state remained 6 min and 20 s. Again, the high power state applied for 1 min period when the aircraft flew at the maximum velocity. The aircraft lowering and the landing period last long for 1 min.

The load current distribution between the UDC and BDC are shown in Figs. 18 and 19. During the startup state, the UDC current is gradually increased after 40 s. After the 40 s, the BDC current flow gradually declines. At 100 s, the UDC current was 2 A and the BDC current was 4 A. Then, the PMS activated the high power state and at the same time, the PEI changed the UDC operating mode into the current control mode. The UDC current was regulated to the maximum 9.2 A and the FC system was operated at the rated current 23.5 A. During the high power state, the BDC was operated in the voltage control mode and supplied 12.5 A current. When the charging state activated, the UDC was switched into the voltage control mode and the BDC was in the buck mode and regulated the current for the battery charging. Fig. 18

The battery SoC variations during the mission is shown in Fig. 22. The battery SoC was reduced during the high power state and the charge level was gradually increased at the charging power state. Based on the FC current which was decided by the power management system, the energy management system optimized the compressor motor power usage. Figure 23 shows the optimized compressor power obtained from the referenced model of the ANFIS controller. When the FC current was high, the compressor power was increased to supply the excess air to the FC system. The charging state consumed less compressor power than the high power state. The compressor power was increased to 10.3 W during the high power state. Fig. 23

The FC system net power outputs with the optimized compressor power and the constant 10 W compressor power were compared. Figure 24 shows the net power output of the FC system with optimized compressor power. The difference between the FC system net power and the FC stack power was high during the high power state and the power deviation reduced during the charging power state. Figure 25 shows that the FC system net power output with the constant compressor power. The compressor operating at the constant power consumed more FC stack power than the actual required compressor power during the charging state. Hence, the constant compressor power configuration loss was higher than the optimized compressor power loss, as shown in Fig. 26. By considering the net power differences at charging state, 2.6 per cent energy saved in the optimized compressor power mode. Fig. 24

sec.title: 8 CONCLUSION
sec.p: In this article, a power and energy management system is proposed for the FC UAV propulsion application. The propulsion power required for the different flying modes such as take-off, climb, endurance, and maximum velocity are defined. The hybrid system operating power is categorized into the three sections called, the start-up state, the charging state, and the high power state. The power management system implements the state sequences based on the feedbacks received from the battery terminal voltage and the DC bus current. The power electronic interface generates the required PWM signals duty ratios in order to control the unidirectional and the bidirectional power converters. The power converters are controlled in the voltage control mode or current control mode depending on the operating power state.

The energy management system is introduced to optimize the FC system energy usage. Based on the FC electrical current which is controlled by the power management system, the FC system inlet air supply system is also controlled. The FC compressor optimum pressure ratio which generates the maximum net power output from the FC system is obtained as a function of the FC current. Then, the optimum compressor power is used as the referenced model for the adaptive neuro-fuzzy controller to adapt the actual compressor power to the optimum value. The FC system net power output is compared with the optimum compressor power and with the constant compressor power and identified 2.6 per cent energy saving in the optimum compressor configuration.

The proposed power and energy management system dynamically controls the hybrid system power flow according to the propulsion power demand. At the same time, the FC controller optimizes the FC system energy utilization and hence consequently extends the UAV endurance capability.
